30/60/90 + Sales Toolkit

Power Home Remodeling — Entry‑Level Sales Representative (Sunrise) • Prepared by Matthew James Carbonell
Sunrise, FL • matthewjamescarbonell@gmail.com
matthewjamescarbonell.com • 305‑764‑2999

North Star

Become a top‑quartile presenter who generates qualified appointments and closed revenue while embodying Power’s culture.

Days 1–30: Learn and Represent

  • Complete new‑hire training modules; shadow top reps; daily role‑plays.
  • Build a personal script library: opener → discovery → demo beats → proof → close → referrals.
  • Activity targets: 12 presentations/week • ≥65% show‑rate • 3 manager‑observed reps.
  • Deliver a 2‑minute demo of windows/insulation (“comfort, quiet, costs”)—on video.

Days 31–60: Produce and Iterate

  • Run full presentations; log wins/objections; A/B test closes and value framing.
  • Integrate incentive framing (e.g., energy‑efficiency credits) to reduce price friction.
  • Lift show‑rate by +10 points; increase proposal→close by +5–10 points vs. first 30 days.
  • Day 45 teach‑back: 10‑minute micro‑lesson on “Two‑question objection isolation.”

Days 61–90: Scale and Contribute

  • Hit ramp quota; request stretch reps (multi‑product jobs); 1 referral per close.
  • Mentor a new hire on demo setup or objection handling; share a 10‑min “what’s working.”
  • Draft SOP for my repeatable prep → pitch → follow‑up workflow.

Success Metrics: Pitches • Shows • Proposals • Closes • Close % • Avg ticket • Referrals • Cycle time.

Interactive Sales Presentation: Eight‑Step Structure

  1. Warm opener: “Thanks for the time. What made you curious about improving the home today?”
  2. Agenda and time check (permission‑based): “We’ll do a quick walkthrough; I’ll show options and pricing; and we’ll decide together on next steps. Sound good?”
  3. Discovery: Current pain (drafts, heat, noise), goals (comfort, bills, curb appeal), timeline/budget, decision process.
  4. Demo (choose product):
    • Windows/doors: seal integrity, glass tech, hardware; illustrate draft/noise reduction.
    • Insulation/siding/roofing: thermal/air barrier; durability; hurricane suitability.
    • Solar: energy offset, roof integration, inverter/app overview (if applicable).
  5. Proof: Before/after stories; simple math: $/month estimates and cost‑of‑waiting (HVAC strain, leaks).
  6. Incentives: Mention relevant energy‑efficiency credits where applicable.
  7. Close (two choices): “Option A handles the major draft points; Option B adds the back bedroom for noise. Which solves more of your daily discomfort?”
  8. Next step: Book install estimate window, recap, confirm follow‑up.

Note: Use impact‑rated solutions where applicable; align with local requirements during proposal.

Talk‑track snippet: “Most families call us for three reasons: comfort, quiet, or costs. Our window system pairs heat‑reflective glass and tight seals to stabilize room temps and cut drafts, with less AC strain, less humidity creep, and noticeably quieter rooms. If we price the project with current incentives, would it help to see a 3‑year vs. 7‑year scenario to decide what makes sense?”

Objection‑Handling Matrix: isolate → label → solve

  • “Price is high.”
    Isolate: “Aside from investment, does it solve the comfort/noise issue?”
    Reframe: “Cost of waiting versus cost of fixing; would a phased approach (front of home now; bedrooms next) help?”
    Proof: brief story + simple math.
  • “We need to think.”
    Isolate: “Is it the scope, timing, or the investment?”
    Close‑on‑process: “Let’s pencil a soft hold for [day/time]; if it’s a ‘no’, we release it, fair?”
  • “I’m getting other quotes.”
    Respect + criteria: “Good call. What will you compare: materials, warranty, install quality, and financing total cost?”
    Value anchor: “If we’re competitive there, are we the pick?”
  • “We don’t have time today.”
    Compress: “Totally. Ten minutes for a demo and a ballpark price, then you decide if it’s worth a full visit.”

Weekly Training Participation Plan

Cadence:

  • Mon: Team coaching camp (film 1 pitch; manager feedback).
  • Wed: Ride‑along + pattern notes (2 takeaways; 1 thing to copy next time).
  • Fri: Role‑play gauntlet (3 objections × 2 variants), log wins/needs.

Artifacts I produce weekly:

  • 1‑page “What worked & why”
  • Updated script library (versioned)
  • Scoreboard screenshot (activity + conversion)

Team Building & Mentorship

  • Buddy a new hire by Day 60 (demo setup; opener).
  • Micro‑lesson (10 min): “Two‑question objection isolation.”
  • Culture contribution: Celebrate weekly wins; share homeowner thank‑yous; volunteer sign‑ups.

Daily/Weekly Scoreboard: Template

Daily: Pitches • Doors knocked/calls made • Shows • Proposals • Closes • Referrals • Notes done.

Weekly Targets: Activity (≥X pitches) • Show rate (≥Y%) • Close rate (≥Z%) • 1 referral per close.

Review: Film‑and‑fix 1 pitch; pick 1 micro‑skill to improve next week.

Follow‑ups & Thank‑Yous

Same‑day recap:
“Thanks again for the time. Here are the 2 options we discussed and the simple math. I’ll call [Day/Time] to answer anything else and, if it’s a fit, lock your spot.”

Post‑interview thank‑you (hiring):
“Appreciate the conversation; your training path and culture really stood out. I’m excited for the chance to contribute in Sunrise and learn the Power way. Thank you again for your time.”
